description.rank: SFI Rank (for all words in 'NGSL Stats & Frequencies to 34K' list)
description.outline: Outline in dictionary, or an outline that works without your having to add anything to the dictionary
description.reason: Simplified outline/notes (please see the Readme for more information regarding this column)
description.alt_outline: Alternate outline/notes (note: alternate outlines may have been remapped to another outline. In addition, outlines identified as such in this section are likely original outlines unless otherwise specified.)
description.rope_story: Story for remembering new outline (or original outline, if there is no new outline)
description.story: Story for remembering original outline (if there is also a new outline) (note: outlines identified as such in this section are likely original outlines unless otherwise specified.)
description.nio: NIO (Non-intuitive outline)? (I should note that with respect to this column, my bar for what constitutes an 'intuitive' outline is pretty low; if the outline has some resemblance to the word it's representing (such as the same first letter), even if it's pretty weak, I'll probably consider it an intuitive outline. However, this list doesn't follow any set standards.)
description.nivlo: NIVLO (Non-Intuitive Vowel-less Outline?) (I have found that vowel-less outlines that aren't intuitive tend to be less than ideal. However, not all NIVLOs are poor outline choices, and it's certainly the case that not all 'voweled'/intuitive outlines are good outline choices. I should note that with respect to this column, my bar for what constitutes an 'intuitive' outline is pretty low; if the outline has some resemblance to the word it's representing (such as the same first letter), even if it's pretty weak, I'll probably consider it an intuitive outline. However, this list doesn't follow any set standards.)
description.change: Outline that you might want to change in the future? (Example: it's a 3-or 4-keypress vowel-less outline that you don't really like.)
description.#rope_keys: #of characters in added-in outline (or pre-existing outline if there's no addition)
description.#rope_strokes: # of strokes, if greater than 1, in the added-in outline (or the original outline if there was no addition)
description.#keys: #Of characters in the original outlines (e.g. excluding added-in outlines)
description.#strokes: #of strokes in the original outline (excluding added-in outlines)
description.#chars: #number of characters in the original English word (counting capitalization and punctuation, but not spaces before/after words)

I'm.reason: "*EUPL overwrites one way to write the ""im-"" prefix."
I'm.alt_outline: "With regard to original outlines for contractions: to add 's,' d, and 'll to ""he,"" ""she,"" and ""we,"" you often just need to use AOE for the vowel and then add in the suffix. (One exception is *EL for ""he'll."") Similarly, to produce I'd, I'll, and I'm, just use AOEU for 'I,' and then add the suffix at the end."
I'm.rope_story: "A boy declares to his friends: ""I'm not scared of PORCUPINES (*). Are you?"""

are.outline: R- or -R (note: I use -R to capitalize words without adding a space)
are.reason: "I use -R to capitalize words while suppressing the space before them, so I write ""are"" exclusively using R-."

they're.reason: "The Phrases in English site indicates that ""they are"" is more common than is ""they're,"" so I use THER for ""they are"" and TH*ER for ""they're."" I also added in TH*ERT for ""they're the."""
they're.alt_outline: "With regard to original outlines: you can create ""they'd,"" ""they're,"" and ""they'll"" just by adding D, R, and L, respectively to the end of THE (for ""they."""

aren't.alt_outline: "With regard to original outlines: you can often form an ""n't"" contraction by adding -PBT to the end of the brief. Examples include aren't, wouldn't, couldn't, isn't, weren't, hadn't, and didn't. Exceptions (or shorter briefs) are found with ""wasn't,"" ""haven't,"" and ""hasn't."""

ain't.rope_story: "It A*EPB (ain't) very common for a PORCUPINE (*) to AEPB (attend) a city council meeting. (AEPB is an addition for ""attend."")"

been.rope_story: "A kid has been busy since Christmas, when he got a BB gun. He  has shot every branch off the tree in his front yard."

wasn't.reason: "WA* is based on the addition of WA for ""was."" In many of my added-in outlines, I use an asterisk to turn an outline into its antonym. In this case, for example, the asterisk turns ""was"" into ""wasn't."" WA* does overwrite ""Washington,"" for which I added in WAS, which overwrites one way to write ""was."""
wasn't.story: Why did the student have to drink 2 Ts (teas) in the morning? Because WUNT (one T) wasn't enough to wake him up.

we're.rope_story: """We're not sure W-R (where) the PORCUPINE (*) is,"" admits a group of students who had released a PORCUPINE (*) into the halls of their school for a prank. (W-R is an outline for ""where."")"

you're.reason: "*UR overwrites one way to write ""you are."" I use UR for ""your,"" which is why I added in this addition."
you're.alt_outline: "With regard to original outlines: to create ""you're,"" ""you'll,"" ""you'd,"" and ""you've,"" just add an R, L, D, or F to the end of U (for ""you"")."

it's.outline: "T-S (or T*S if you use T-S for ""its"")"
it's.reason: "I use T-S for ""its,"" which is why I use T*S for ""it's."""

there's.rope_story: "There's a reason why so many people visit TOKYO (T-): it has great food and L-S (also) features lots of cultural attractions. (HR-S is an outline for ""also."")"

why's.rope_story: """Why's the sky the limit?"" asks an astronaut. ""Why not say that the STARS (*) are the limit?"" (This story is just meant to help you remember that there's an asterisk in this outline.)"

where's.rope_story: """A ROLLER COASTER (-R) that only goes 10 miles an hour? Where's the fun in that?"" asks your friend."

he's.rope_story: "Students say of a high schooler with a distinctive hairstyle: ""Maybe he was born like thator maybe he's really a PORCUPINE (*)."""

she's.reason: "The Phrases in English site indicates that ""she's"" is more common than ""she is"" (to which SHES is mapped)."
she's.rope_story: """SH (sh)! She's sleeping!"" a woman says of her friend to a crowd of tourists in Ibiza, SPAIN (-S)."

who's.rope_story: "Who's going to take a sick PORCUPINE (*) off the side of the road and into their home? A nature lover, that's who. "
who's.story: "(Story for WHOES, if you prefer that outline: A college senior asks himself: ""who's going to pay all my student loan DEBT (OE)? My parents, I hope."")"

here's.reason: "H*RS (which overwrites ""hrs,"" for which I added in HO*URS, which would normally produce {^-hours}) is based on the addition of H-R for ""here."""
here's.rope_story: """And here's a PORCUPINE (*)! What an exciting thing to find H-R (here)!"" is not something that you want your real estate agent to say while showing you a house in rural SPAIN (-S). (H-R is an addition for ""here."")"

and.reason: "AP overwrites ""app,"" for which I added in APG. Note that SKP- is still used in many phrases that incorporate ""and."" Although it may seem strange to use two different forms of a word (one for the word by itself and one for phrases), this is already seen in Plover's original dictionary (e.g. -PT for ""want"" and -BS for ""said"" in phrases). Due to the presence of all the phrases that use SKP-, you may actually find yourself using SKP- more frequently than AP for ""and."""
and.rope_story: "The AP style manual will help you learn how to correctly use the word ""and"" in a sentence."

to.reason: "Use O instead of TO for ""to"" at your own risk, as O is a stroke used in multiple 2+ stroke outlines. However, I figure that saving the keypress is worth it, as all of the words in ROPE can be written in just one keypress (so those two-keypress outlines that use O as a stroke aren't that common). In addition, I added in OB for ""to be,"" which overwrites a misstroke entry for ""on."""

a.reason: "This addition overwrites the ""a-"" prefix (for which I use AEU). Although it's obviously an important prefix, none of the top 4000 words in ROPE use it (because all the outlines are a single stroke). Therefore, I think it's better to use A for ""a,"" which is one of the most common words in English. If you do use A for ""a,"" you'll probably have to add in a lot of additional outlines to overwrite word boundary errors, but I personally think that this change is worth it."

haven't.rope_story: """I haven't got a clue what my job responsibilities are,"" a new VP (Vice Precedent) admits to the media."
haven't.story: "A kid declares to you: ""As long as I have a jar of crunchy PB (peanut butter), I SR (have) no need for anything else."" (SR is the outline for ""have."")"

we've.rope_story: """WEF (we've) accomplished something amazing,"" agree a team of scientists who managed to launch an ELEPHANT (E) into the STARS (*). However, they're not sure if they'll be able to bring him back down OK."

hasn't.reason: "HA*S is based on HAS for ""has,"" and overwrites ""Haas,"" for which I added in HA*US, which overwrites ""Haus."" The asterisk negates the meaning of ""has"" and turns it into ""hasn't."""
hasn't.story: "A hunter hasn't got a clue why he's in the ACCIDENT AND EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT. The reason is that while H(u)NT-ing (hunting), he fell off a tree and got knocked unconscious."

hadn't.rope_story: A senior laments during graduation that HS (high school) hadn't been as fun as kindergarten.

I'd.reason: "EUD overwrites ""id,"" for which I added in AO*ED, which overwrites ""he'd,"" for which I added in H*D."
I'd.rope_story: """I'd say that the subject of the EUD (id) is somewhat dated in modern psychology,"" your professor says."

you've.reason: "*UF overwrites ""UV,"" for which I added in SRAOU, which overwrites ""view,"" for which I added in SRU. (I use UF for ""you have."")"

could've.alt_outline: "With regard to original outlines: could've, would've, and should've are made by adding *UF to the end of the briefs for could, would, and should."

would've.reason: "WO*F is based on the addition of WOF for ""would have."""

should've.rope_story: "When everyone studying hard at the UF (University of Florida) Library tells your pet PORCUPINE (*) to SH (shh), you realize that you SH*UF (should've) left him at home."

its.reason: "T-S overwrites ""it's,"" for which I added in T*S, which overwrites ""it is,"" for which you can use ST*. (Note that ST- is ""is it."") T-S is simply T- for ""it"" with S for the ""-s"" ending."

your.reason: "UR overwrites ""you're,"" for which I added in *UR, which overwrites one way to write ""you are."" Note that UR corresponds nicely with URS for ""yours."""

yours.rope_story: """Yours truly is spending quite a bit of time in URS (Uris) Hall these days,"" a busy Columbia MBA student says to his friend."

him.rope_story: """ET is lost, so I'm going to HONDURAS (H-) to find him"" is an unusual way to ask your boss for extra vacation time."

their.rope_story: The city of TOKYO (T-) wishes that their local ROLLER COASTERS (-R) were just as tall as Mount Fuji.

say.reason: "SAE overwrites ""sea,"" for which I added in SAEU, which overwrites the original outline for ""say."""

one.reason: "I also added in WUFB for ""one of."""

he'd.story: "If a man is taking a trip to DALLAS (-D) in the summer, he'd better bring some MOSQUITO (AOE) repellent."

good.reason: "OD overwrites ""odd,"" for which I added in AOD. I use WOERT for ""better."" I also added in WOERPB for ""better than,"" which overwrites one way to write ""worn,"" and -BS for ""best."""

"
